chapter.title: Automating Simulation Sessions with &ecell Session Script

highlights.para:
By reading this chapter, you can get information about the following items:
What is &ecell Session Script (ESS).
How to automate the simulation by writing the ESS files.
How to run &ecell in scripting mode.
How to customize existing frontend software components. How to write a new frontend program to &ecell&.

sect1.title: Running &ecell Session Script
sect1.para:
There are roughly three ways to execute ESS;
Execute the script from operating system's command line (shell prompt).
Load the script from a frontend software such as Osogo Session Monitor.
Use SessionManager to automate the invokation of the simulation sessions, as well as the generation of the ESS itself, for simulations involving multiple runs of the simulator.

sect2.title: Running the ESS in command line mode
sect2.para: To run a ESS in command line, use ecell3-session command.

sect3.title: In batch mode
sect3.para:
To execute a ESS file, type the following command at the shell prompt:
$ ecell3-session filename.ess
ecell3-session command loads the ESS file and runs a single simulation session as described in the file.

sect3.title: In interactive mode
sect3.para:
To run the ecell3-session in interactive mode, invoke the command without the filename argument.
$ ecell3-session ecell3-session [ for E-Cell SE Version 3, on Python Version 2.2.1 ] Copyright (C) 1996-2002 Keio University. Written by Kouichi Takahashi shafi@e-cell.org ecell3-session>>>
The banner and the prompt shown here may vary according to the version you are using.

sect1.title: Writing &ecell Session Script
sect1.para: The syntax of ESS is a full set of Python script with some convenient features.
Three major groups of object classes which are commonly used in ESS are Session, ObjectStub classes, and Datafile classes.
This section explains how to use these classes in your ESS.

sect3.title: General rules
sect3.para: In ESS, usualy an instance of Session is given, and any methods defined in the class can be used as if it is defined in global namespace.

For example, to run the simulation for 10 seconds, you may use run method of a Session object in your ESS file.
self.run( 10 )
where self. is the current Session object given by the system. Alternatively you can use theSession as the self.
theSession.run( 10 )

Unlike usual Python script, you can omit the object on which the method is called if the object is the current Session.
run( 10 )

sect3.title: Loading a model
sect3.para:
Let's try this in the interactive mode of the ecell3-session command. On the prompt of the command, you may load a model by using loadModel() method.
ecell3-session>>> loadModel( 'simple.eml' )
Then the prompt changes from ecell3-session>>> to model name, t=current time>>>
simple.eml, t=0>>>

sect3.title: Running the simulation
sect3.para: To proceed the time by executing the simulation, step() and run() methods are used.
step() conducts a single step of the simulation

sect3.title: What is ObjectStub?
sect3.para: Explanation of backend/frontend isolation may come here.
The following example loads an EML file, and prints the value of ATP Variable in System /CELL every 10 seconds. If the value is below 1000, it stops the simulation.

example.title: An ESS to check ATP level every 10 seconds
example.programlisting:
loadModel( 'simple.eml' )
ATP = createEntityStub( 'Variable:/CELL:ATP' )
while 1:
ATPValue = ATP[ 'Value' ]
message( 'ATP value = %s' % ATPValue )
if ATPValue <= 1000: break
run( 10 )
message( 'Stopped at %s.' % getCurrentTime() )
